March 18, 1990: Fiction
THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) A
professor's past association with Vietnamese terrorists catches up with him, with
dramatic consequences.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life, as depicted in verse and pictures.
DEVICES AND DESIRES, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $19.95.) Adam Dalgitesh
puzzles over a series of killings on the windy Norfolk coast.
THE BAD PLACE by Dean R. Koontz (Putnam, $10.95.) A troubled sleepwalker
hires a detective team to discover the causes and consequences of his behavior.
CLEAR AND PRESENT DANGER, by Tom Clancy (Putnam, $21.95.) The C.I.A.'s
Jack Ryan fights Colombian drug lords.
THE SCIONS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.)
The adventures of two brothers who practice magic in a fantasy land where its use
is forbidden.
BITTER SWEET by LaVyrie Spencer. (Putnam, $18.95.) A widow's ordeal after
meeting her high school flame, now a less than happily married man.
COUNTERATTACK, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $16.95.) The Marines in action,
from Pearl Harbor to Guadalcanal, third volume in "The Corps" series.
A RULING PASSION, by Judith Michael (Poseidon, $19.95.) A young widow's
entry into the world of television brings her adventures fraught with love, intrigue,
revenge and murder.
CARIBBEAN, by James A. Michener (Random House, $22.95.) The history of the
sea islands told in fictional form.
VINELAND, by Thomas Pynchon (Little, Brown ($19.95.) The passions of the
1960's continue to rule the lives of members of a community in Northern
California.
COLD HARBOUR, by Jack Higgins (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The O.S.S. agent
Craig Osbourne on a perilous mission during World War II.
DADDY, by Danielle Steel (Delacorte, $19.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe,
predictable world a man has built for himself and his family.
ANY WOMAN'S BLUES, by Erica Jong. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) One woman's
odyssey from the '60's to the '90's, marked by drugs, travel, high living, marriage
and motherhood.
March 18, 1990
Non-Fiction
MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene (Morrow, $21.95.)
Prognostications about political, economic and social developments in the next
decade.
BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar (Harper &
Row, $22.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco.
LIAR'S POKER, by Michael Lewis (Norton, $18.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous
1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader.
WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION, by Peggy Noonan. (Random House,
$19.95.) The memoirs of a speechwriter for Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum (Villard,
$17.95.) A new collection of inspirational essays.
THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An astrophysicist
tells how he stalked a computer hacker from California across America to West
Germany.
ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert
Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking (Bantam, $18.95.) A
scientist views efforts to create a unified theory of the universe.
PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS, by Vladimir Pozner. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) The
autobiography of a man raised in New York, who became a commentator for
Radio Moscow.
THE SPY WENT DANCING, by Aline, Countess of Romanones. (Putnam,
$19.95.) A World War II O.S.S. operative resumes her investigations during the
THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA, by Robert M. Bork (Free Press, $22.50.) A
critique of the relationship between politics and the law by Ronald Reagan's
Supreme Court nominee.
THE EMPEROR'S NEW MIND, by Roger Penrose (Oxford University, $24.95.) A
physicist maintains that computers will never replace human thinking.
THE SECOND WORLD WAR, by John Keegan. (Viking, $29.95.) A military
history.
HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton, $19.95.) How the brain affects the
endocrine and immune systems.
